metadata.title: BMC Public Health Influenza pandemic and professional duty: family or patients first? A survey of hospital employees

abstract.original_text: Background: Conflicts between professional duties and fear of influenza transmission to family members may arise among health care professionals (HCP).

sentences.segment_text: Background : Conflicts between professional duties and fear of influenza transmission to family members may arise among health care professionals ( HCP ) .

abstract.original_text: We surveyed employees at our university hospital regarding ethical issues arising during the management of an influenza pandemic.

sentences.segment_text: We surveyed employees at our university hospital regarding ethical issues arising during the management of an influenza pandemic .

abstract.original_text: Of 644 respondents, 182 (28%) agreed that it would be professionally acceptable for HCP to abandon their workplace during a pandemic in order to protect themselves and their families, 337 (52%) disagreed with this statement and 125 (19%) had no opinion, with a higher rate of disagreement among physicians (65%) and nurses (54%) compared with administrators (32%). Of all respondents, 375 (58%) did not believe that the decision to report to work during a pandemic should be left to the individual HCP and 496 (77%) disagreed with the statement that HCP should be permanently dismissed for not reporting to work during a pandemic. Only 136 (21%) respondents agreed that HCW without children should primarily care for the influenza patients.

sentences.segment_text: Of 644 respondents , 182 ( 28 % ) agreed that it would be professionally acceptable for HCP to abandon their workplace during a pandemic in order to protect themselves and their families ,
337 ( 52 % ) disagreed with this statement and 125 ( 19 % ) had no opinion ,
with a higher rate of disagreement among physicians ( 65 % ) and nurses ( 54 % ) compared with administrators ( 32 % ) .

Of all respondents , 375 ( 58 % ) did not believe that the decision to report to work during a pandemic should be left to the individual HCP and 496 ( 77 % ) disagreed with the statement that HCP should be permanently dismissed for not reporting to work during a pandemic .
Only 136 ( 21 % ) respondents agreed that HCW without children should primarily care for the influenza patients .

abstract.original_text: Our results suggest that a modest majority of HCP, but only a minority of hospital administrators, recognises the obligation to treat patients despite the potential risks. Professional ethical guidelines allowing for balancing the needs of society with personal risks are needed to help HCP fulfil their duties in the case of a pandemic influenza.
